page.title: 05BRICKMAKING - PROBLEMS
page.content:
1. Over 1,500 acres of good farm land has been worked and little has been returned to agricultural use.
2. L.B.C. have refused to fill in pits if it costs money and therefore there is an increasing amount of derelict land.
3. The smell from the brickworks can be a great nuisance.
4. Pollution containing sulphur dioxide and fluorine is produced. A Beds Times reporter (1978) suggested a farmer stood to lose much money because his cattle are consuming contaminated grass, and probably as a result were suffering from a bone disease called Fluorosis. It was suggested that back complaints in the area may also be caused by this.
